4.60.text: These people are amongst the greatest quiz players in Britain.

9.96.text: Together, they make up the Eggheads,

11.84.text: arguably the most formidable quiz team in the country.

17.40.text: The question is, can they be beaten?

23.44.text: Welcome to Eggheads, the show where a team of five quiz Challengers

27.28.text: pit their wits against possibly the greatest quiz team in Britain.

33.36.text: And taking on the might of our quiz Goliaths

36.56.text: are Run Camden from London. This team of friends met

40.16.text: through their shared love of running

42.20.text: and regularly pound the pavements of north London together.

46.88.text: Hi, I'm Sam. I'm the manager of a running shop.

49.76.text: Hi, I'm John and I'm the assistant manager of a running shop.

53.12.text: Hi, I'm Emma and I'm studying for a PhD in neuromuscular diseases.

57.20.text: Hi, I'm Jonny and I'm an insurance claims handler.

59.64.text: Hi, I'm Charlotte and I'm a projects manager for a theatre company.

63.32.text:
- So, Sam, team, welcome. 
- Hello. 
- Good to see you.

66.72.text:
- You run together, do you? 
- That's right, yeah.

69.56.text: Every single week... John and I are there every week

72.44.text: and the others are there almost every week.

75.00.text: When I said you pound the pavements of north London,

77.48.text: I think that's not easy cos there's a lot of people on those pavements.

80.96.text: There's a lot of parks, there's a lot of different places that we go -

84.16.text: Hampstead Heath, lots of lovely places to run.

86.28.text:
- And you are quizzers, some of you. 
- In theory. 
- OK, I won't ask any more.

90.80.text: Good luck. Every day, there is £1,000-worth of cash

93.60.text: up for grabs for our Challengers.

95.48.text: However, if they fail to defeat the Eggheads,

97.64.text: the prize money rolls over to the next show.

100.00.text: So, runners, I can tell you

101.48.text: that the Eggheads have been on a bit of a marathon here,

104.48.text: doing really well, stayed on their feet.

108.60.text: so that means there's £19,000 to play for today. How's that?

112.20.text: You didn't know that, did you? I've surprised you with a number.

115.36.text: The first head-to-head battle is on the subject of Sport.

117.80.text:
- That should be perfect. 
- Should be.

119.92.text:
- Who would like it? 
- Choose a player. Sport. 
- One of you two.

123.44.text: I should think, seeing as we work together

126.44.text: and talk about sport all the time,

128.60.text:
- I'm OK but John's a little bit better. 
- Yeah.

131.04.text: So, it's got to be John.

132.52.text: Against which Egghead? John, you can choose any one of them.

135.36.text: Pat's enjoying being squeezed in the middle there.

137.84.text:
- We could try and get Barry out. 
- I think Lisa. 
- Yeah.

141.56.text: Shot in the dark, but Lisa. Why not? Try and get Lisa out.

145.52.text: OK, John from Run Camden versus Lisa from the Eggheads.

150.12.text: would you please both take your positions in our Question Room?

154.84.text: So, John, you were brought up in Cuba.

156.92.text: Yes, I was born in Cuba and spent the first six months there

160.24.text: and then spent some time in Portugal

162.36.text: before coming back to Scotland, so well travelled.

165.28.text: Fantastic route around the world there. Why were you in Cuba?

167.96.text: My dad used to work as a foreign correspondent,

170.52.text: so he was based out in a few different countries

173.08.text: and he happened to be in Cuba when I was on the way.

176.20.text: 30 years ago, they were really a hot topic.

179.44.text: Yeah, certainly it was quite an interesting place to work.

182.04.text: I've been back a couple of times and it's certainly quite a place.

185.48.text: And Sport - I know you work in the shop, selling the running shoes,

188.68.text: so running is your sport. Anything else?

194.04.text: I know a lot about football but not very good at it.

196.60.text:
- So, Sport, John, your choice - first or second? 
- Can I go second, please?

203.88.text: Second... OK, the runners are throwing us a googly there.

207.68.text: Lisa, the footballer Vincent Kompany usually plays in which position?

215.92.text: He ain't a goalkeeper but he's definitely up the back, I think.

219.44.text:
- He's a defender. 
- Defender is correct. Well done.

222.48.text:
- You would have known that, I'm thinking, John? 
- Yeah, yeah.

228.00.text: Which of these men's international rugby union teams

230.44.text: performs the haka before their games?

236.32.text: Um, I'm going to have to go with New Zealand there.

239.28.text: It is, indeed, New Zealand. Well done. They might get harder.

244.28.text: Which of these sportsmen celebrated their 40th birthday in 2015?

253.84.text: Er, 2015... Now, I think Chris Hoy's that little bit younger

264.04.text: I know an awful lot about David Beckham,

265.92.text: for reasons that are not entirely sporting,

268.40.text: but we'll go with David Beckham.

270.04.text: David Beckham is the right answer. You're a fan, are you?

272.96.text:
- Oh, who isn't? 
- I was in a restaurant or cafe the other day,

276.12.text: having breakfast, and I recognised him at one of the tables.

279.40.text: You mean he didn't come over and go,

281.56.text: "It's Jeremy Vine! Can I get a selfie?"

284.04.text: No, all I could think to say was, "Respect", like that.

287.04.text: He said, "Thank you," very politely and that was it.

289.36.text: So I've said one work to him, literally one word.

295.08.text: Who holds the record for the most weeks

297.56.text: as the world's number one-ranked male golfer?

305.12.text: I think Greg Norman never won a major, as far as I'm aware.

310.08.text: Um... For all his recent travails, I'd have to say Tiger Woods.

314.00.text: Yeah, travails apart, it is Tiger Woods.

316.32.text: You're right and you're equal with Lisa,

318.80.text: who has the chance for three in a row now.

320.80.text: In tennis, what name is given to the right side of the court,

324.08.text: from which the serve is made and received at even-numbered points?

331.48.text: Ah, see, I knew one side was the ace court

333.60.text: and one side was the deuce court,

335.40.text: I just don't know which way round they are.

339.48.text: I think it's the ace court, but I'm not sure. I'll go with it anyway.

342.68.text:
- Ace court. 
- I would definitely have guessed that.

345.28.text:
- It's the deuce court, isn't it? 
- Well, it's an absolute stinker.

348.80.text:
- It's deuce court, Lisa. 
- Argh! 
- So, here we are.

353.80.text: Chance to show her a clean pair of trainers, John.

357.08.text: The New Orleans Pelicans are a top-tier team in which sport?

360.36.text: The New Orleans Pelicans. Is it...?

367.36.text: Well, American football is the Saints. Basketball...

372.12.text: Oh, it had been the Hornets, but they moved back to Charlotte

376.44.text: and ice hockey, I have to admit, I'm not sure.

378.64.text:
- I'm going to go with basketball. 
- You've got a bit of knowledge there.

382.96.text: You think it was the New Orleans Hornets, was it?

385.24.text: Previously, cos they were in Charlotte,

387.56.text: then they moved to New Orleans,

389.16.text: but I think they moved back in Carolina, so I think the Pelicans...

395.20.text:
- We think it's ice hockey but we could be wrong. 
- Ice hockey, yeah.

398.36.text: OK, I'm glad they're playing you, John, cos you got it right.

401.08.text:
- Basketball is the answer. 
- Nice one! Well done, John. 
- Three out of three.

404.16.text: You're in the final round. You've beaten Lisa.

409.68.text: Come back to us and we'll play the next round.

413.40.text: OK, this is going to be lively, I can tell. Trainers on, Eggheads.

417.52.text: You're a little bit complacent out of the starting gate, I think.

421.12.text: As it stands, Run Camden have got all their brains.

424.00.text: The Eggheads have had one knocked out.

425.96.text: We're playing for a lot of money here - £19,000.

428.40.text: The next subject is Film & TV.

432.80.text: I think we've discussed in advance, haven't we, who's going to be that.

435.96.text:
- Charlotte. 
- Works in theatre. 
- Yep. 
- OK. 
- Charlotte. 
- Yeah.

439.84.text: OK, Charlotte, against which Egghead? They're all here, ready.

443.72.text:
- Lisa can't. 
- Pat? 
- Yeah? 
- Pat? 
- Do you want to go for Pat?

447.44.text:
- OK. 
- Sure? 
- Pat. Win! 
- Pat. Win. LAUGHTER

452.08.text: OK, Pat lose, maybe. Here we go.

455.60.text: Charlotte from Run Camden versus Pat from the Eggheads.

458.52.text: To ensure there's no conferring, please go to our Question Room.

462.80.text: This will be good for you, I'm thinking, Charlotte, because you...

465.68.text: Well, tell us what your job is.

467.44.text: So, I'm a projects manager for a theatre company.

471.08.text: OK, so a lot of acting and stage and what kind of stuff?

473.92.text: So, we predominantly do family theatre,

477.72.text: so we're a touring a company.

479.68.text: We tour all over the world and in the UK.

481.84.text: Brilliant and a huge demand for that.

483.84.text:
- Yeah. 
- I know, as a father of young girls,

486.16.text: you just long for productions which they enjoy.

488.92.text: Yeah, and we really try and make them

491.40.text: so that they're for the whole family to enjoy - the parents as well -

494.52.text: because they're the ones booking the tickets

497.00.text: so we want them to have a good time as well.

499.60.text: And you're running with your teammates, is that right?

502.28.text:
- Yeah, as much as I can, yeah. 
- Good stuff. Good luck against Pat.

505.96.text: Film & TV. Charlotte, would you like to go first or second?

513.48.text: So, the first question goes to Pat.

515.52.text: What genre is the 2014 Christopher Nolan film Interstellar?

523.96.text: I think this was a huge budget sci-fi film

528.64.text: with people like Matthew McConaughey in it.

530.92.text: I'm not sure it really triumphed at the box office,

533.72.text: but it's a big science fiction film.

536.40.text: It is, indeed, a big science fiction film, not a Western.

544.28.text: as the new main presenter of the TV show Top Gear in June, 2015?

553.52.text: Um, I'm fairly certain that it's Chris Evans.

557.88.text: He talked about it quite a lot on his radio show, so Chris Evans.

562.60.text:
- What station does he work on? 
- Radio 2. 
- Oh, OK, right.

566.24.text: I've heard that's good. Chris Evans is the right answer.

571.68.text: Who plays Alan Harper in the TV series Two And A Half Men?

582.96.text: I've not been a regular viewer of this programme,

586.60.text: so it's going to be a bit of a guess, I'm afraid.

592.76.text: I will guess at John Krasinski.

595.20.text:
- Do you know, Charlotte? 
- I don't.

596.88.text: I would have gone for the same one, actually, so...

599.64.text:
- Jon Cryer is the answer. 
- Ah!

602.24.text: So, Charlotte, your chance to take the lead.

605.16.text: This is getting a bit exciting, this contest.

607.76.text: Which actor has been married to Scarlett Johansson and Blake Lively?

620.04.text: So, I'm going to rule out Colin Farrell.

623.16.text: Um, I know that Josh Hartnett and Scarlett Johansson

629.60.text: but I know that Blake Lively is married to Ryan Reynolds.

637.84.text: I'm going to go for Ryan Reynolds.

640.24.text: Ryan Reynolds is your answer. Well done, you're right.

643.40.text: Pat, let's put those thoughts of Scarlett Johansson aside

645.96.text: and here is your third question.

650.12.text: is played on TV by the Danish actor Mads Mikkelsen?

660.12.text: I think he plays the serial killer Hannibal Lecter.

665.60.text: Hannibal Lecter is right. Well done. You've got two out of three, Pat,

669.00.text: but if Charlotte gets this right, she is in the final round,

671.56.text: otherwise we go to Sudden Death.

673.72.text: Who directed the films Scarface, Carrie and Mission: Impossible?

687.44.text: I've seen Mission: Impossible. I've not seen the other two. Er...

691.68.text: I'm not sure it's Martin Scorsese,

695.32.text: so I think I'm going to go for...

698.92.text: ..Brian de Palma, although that might be wrong, thinking about it.

704.28.text: Brian de Palma is your answer.

705.76.text: There was a little murmur from the Eggheads.

708.00.text:
- Why did you murmur, Eggs? 
- Cos she's right.

709.96.text: Because they know they've lost two players.

712.00.text: Charlotte, you're in the final round.

714.08.text: Brian de Palma is the right answer. Pat's been knocked out.

716.68.text: Oh, and we're playing for £19,000 as well.

719.88.text: Can't wait to get on with the next round. Please come back to us.

724.24.text: Well, Run Camden... Sam, just a bit of an update from you?

728.16.text:
- How are you feeling? 
- It's going well. 
- Where are we on the marathon?

731.04.text:
- It's 26 miles for a marathon, so we're on...mile 10? 
- Not even that.

735.64.text:
- It's all down to the final round, isn't it? 
- Yeah, good point.

740.68.text: so no chickens being counted here, to mix our metaphors.

744.36.text: But you have taken two Eggheads out

746.32.text: and gently pushed them off the cliff.

748.64.text: So, Run Camden, you're playing really well

750.52.text: and this is a big jackpot we're playing for. They've lost no brains.

753.60.text: Let's see what happens now. The subject is Science.

755.92.text: That's quite obvious who we're going to go for.

758.32.text:
- We'll go for the scientist. 
- We have a PhD student here. 
- Yes.

761.56.text: OK, Emma, against which Egghead? It can be Judith or Barry or Dave.

766.08.text:
- I think Dave. I think... 
- You're the captain. 
- I'd like Dave.

770.44.text:
- OK. 
- It's got to be Dave. 
- Dave, Dave. 
- Dave, you are, what is it?

775.56.text:
- The boy with the finger in the dyke now? 
- Yeah, the guinea pig.

778.56.text: OK, Emma from Run Camden against Dave from the Eggheads.

781.68.text: The Eggheads on the back foot here. Please go to the Question Room.

788.16.text: They said you are the scientist, so tell us.

790.20.text: Yeah, I'm studying for a PhD in neuromuscular diseases,

793.72.text: so a fairly niche area of science.

796.12.text: But then that does in a way, fit in

798.48.text:
- with all the running that you all do. 
- Yes, absolutely.

803.08.text: something like motor neurone, would it, or something?

805.64.text: Absolutely, so motor neurone disease or some of the rarer ones,

810.84.text: Good luck against Dave. This is an interesting contest today, Dave.

815.64.text: You've come in at the right moment to hold the fort for the Eggheads.

818.60.text:
- Good luck with that, yeah. 
- Emma, Science.

820.64.text:
- Do you want to go first or second? 
- Second, please, Jeremy.

829.52.text: For what does the medical abbreviation DVT stand?

838.84.text:
- It's deep vein thrombosis. 
- Yes, it is deep vein thrombosis.

843.44.text:
- On aeroplanes, people wear special socks, don't they? 
- Yeah.

849.52.text: What type of marine creature is a conch?

856.56.text: Can you spell the creature for me?

863.00.text: I'm going to plump down the middle with sea snail.

866.72.text: Yes, it is sea snail. Well done, Emma. One point each.

870.92.text:
- Have you even got a question wrong yet? 
- No, they haven't. 
- Have they?

874.64.text:
- They can't have. 
- No. 
- I don't think they have. 
- No, they haven't yet.

879.44.text: Which of these was a type of prehistoric shark?

887.00.text: I've got no idea. I'm going to rule out megalosaurus.

892.04.text: Smilodon would be an eloquent... I'll have to go mega...

898.64.text: Megatherium, with no confidence at all.

903.16.text:
- You're going megatherium? 
- Mmm-hmm. 
- You got it wrong, Dave.

906.56.text:
- Is it "don"? 
- It's megalodon. Judith kept saying "don". It's "don".

910.76.text:
- You're being eaten by a shark here. 
- Yes! 
- OK, so here we are again.

915.00.text: Get this right, take the lead.

916.88.text: According to the RSPB, which coast-dwelling water bird

920.68.text: is the UK's heaviest and fastest-flying duck?

928.68.text: Um...I think I'm going to go for eider.

933.28.text: Eider is right. Well done. They're so purposeful, this team.

937.00.text: They're not even applauding their own players.

939.24.text: They're like, "We're running towards the money."

943.64.text:
- precipice - you feel it? 
- I'm on the edge.

946.72.text:
- Feel the breeze? 
- Yeah. 
- Hear the sea below? 
- Yeah.

949.20.text: You're off the edge if you get this wrong.

951.20.text: What was the nationality of the scientist after whom the ampere,

954.28.text: the SI unit of electrical current, takes its name?

965.48.text: I've got an instinct for French but, again, it's...

969.16.text:
- I'm on the edge, so, French. 
- Yeah, it does sound like a French word.

973.76.text: French is right, so you've got two out of three.

976.96.text: This is a crucial moment in the contest now.

979.00.text: If you get this right, you will have knocked out Dave

981.56.text: and three Eggheads will be gone. Take your time here.

984.48.text: Stibium is an obsolete name for which chemical element?

996.72.text: Er, I'm going to rule out bismuth and antimony

1002.76.text:
- and go with cadmium. 
- Cadmium is your answer.

1005.92.text: So, in other words, stibium was the old name

1008.56.text: and it's not used any more for one of these.

1011.08.text: If you've got it right, Dave will be out

1012.92.text: and three Eggheads will be down, which doesn't happen very often.

1015.76.text:
- Barry, do you know? 
- It's antimony. 
- It is antimony. How do we know that?

1019.24.text:
- Can we guess that somehow or not? 
- I don't think it's guessable.

1022.32.text: Yes, it is, cos I did it. The chemical symbol for antimony is Sb.

1026.36.text: Ah! So, what we've got here, Emma,

1029.04.text: is that the chemical symbol for antimony, Lisa says, is Sb.

1033.52.text:
- Ah-ha. 
- Stibium is the old word for antimony.

1036.52.text:
- You've got it wrong, so you're now equal with Dave. 
- OK.

1039.72.text: So, we go to Sudden Death.

1041.64.text: Gets a bit harder now. I don't give you alternatives.

1044.16.text: Your question, Dave. The tarsier is a primate found in which continent?

1054.72.text: Tarsier. Not heard of it. Um...

1061.76.text: It's a small, large-eyed, leaping primate, native to Southeast Asia.

1066.68.text:
- Right, OK. 
- Got it wrong. Sudden Death.

1068.84.text: Emma, get this right, you will be in the final,

1071.44.text: after the team's first wrong answer of the whole contest.

1075.32.text: In which city was the scientist Marie Curie born in 1867?

1085.68.text: Obviously, she's associated with France, so I'm going to say Paris.

1094.44.text: "I eat green caterpillars" is a mnemonic

1097.04.text: to help remember the four largest satellites of which planet?

1104.96.text: So, Io, Europa, Callisto and Ganymede.

1110.00.text: Mind's gone blank there, but I'll go Jupiter.

1113.32.text: You did well because you got the satellites as well.

1116.72.text: It is Io, Europa, Ganymede, Callisto.

1120.64.text: The answer is Jupiter. You're correct.

1122.56.text: For the first time in the contest,

1126.44.text: Emma, you need to get this right to stay in.

1128.40.text: In which category was Werner Heisenberg

1136.24.text: I don't recognise the name, so based on that,

1139.24.text: I'm going to say maybe not medicine and physiology.

1145.08.text:
- I'm going to take a guess at chemistry. 
- Chemistry is your answer.

1149.72.text: Now, the name has become very famous recently

1151.76.text:
- because, am I right, Breaking Bad? 
- Yeah. 
- He calls himself Heisenberg.

1155.56.text: And I think Heisenberg... It was Heisenberg's rule of what is it?

1160.44.text:
- I'm uncertain about that. 
- The uncertainty principle. 
- Yes.

1163.68.text: Anything you observe, you change. And the answer is physics.

1169.12.text: Emma, you've been knocked out by Dave, on Sudden Death.

1171.48.text: Dave is in the final round.

1173.28.text: The Eggheads pulling back a bit here.

1175.08.text: First bump in the road for our runners.

1177.08.text: Do come back to us and we'll play the last round before the final.

1182.20.text: So, Run Camden hit a little problem there and Heisenberg was the reason.

1186.28.text: We know Heisenberg now, from Breaking Bad,

1188.48.text: because that's the code name that Walter White gives himself.

1191.28.text: Barry, over to you with Science.

1192.72.text: It's surprising he gave himself that because he was a chemist

1197.08.text: But Heisenberg's famous for his uncertainty principle,

1199.96.text: which says you can know the speed of an object

1202.32.text: or you can know its position but you can't know both.

1205.36.text: All right, Heisenberg, are we there?

1207.32.text: So, Emma's been knocked out. The next subject is Politics.

1210.88.text: Who would like this from the runners,

1215.60.text: I think they're hard, aren't they, but you can give it a go.

1219.80.text: Take your pick, Jonny. Who are you going to take on?

1222.64.text:
- So, Jonny... 
- I think, if we can knock Barry out...

1226.00.text: If we can knock any of them out if would be good.

1228.36.text:
- I'd like to take on Barry, please. 
- Good stuff.

1230.40.text: You can see he's good on Science. Maybe the Politics is lacking.

1233.12.text: Let's hope so. Jonny from Run Camden versus Barry from the Eggheads.

1237.24.text: To ensure there's no conferring, please take your positions.

1241.48.text: Jonny, you have an interest in Politics

1243.44.text: or did you just get press-ganged there?

1245.72.text: I think it was Sam's doing.

1247.36.text: I was hoping for Geography but it's the luck of the draw,

1250.32.text:
- so I'm in and I'm ready to answer a few questions. 
- All right. Good luck.

1254.80.text:
- Thank you. 
- Would you like to go first or second?

1257.12.text: Rule of thumb is second, so I'll stick with that, please.

1263.24.text: Barry, you, therefore, have the first question.

1265.88.text: The parliament of which country is located in Holyrood?

1272.12.text: If I get this wrong, I shall have to go home and hang my head in shame.

1275.52.text: The answer to that question is Scotland.

1278.04.text: Yes, you're right. Well done, Barry.

1282.92.text: did the Conservative party win at the 2015 UK general election?

1292.36.text: I know they got an overall majority and you need 326 to do that,

1298.64.text: Bang on, well done. Not everybody knows that.

1301.28.text: 331 is the right answer. Barry, your question.

1305.16.text: Which Nobel prize was the former US president Jimmy Carter

1313.12.text: Although he started out his career in a scientific discipline,

1316.20.text: cos he worked on nuclear submarines for a while,

1318.48.text: I believe he won the Peace Prize.

1320.64.text: He did win the Peace Prize. Well done. Peace it is.

1323.88.text: Jonny, what is the first real name

1326.00.text: of Jeb Bush, son of George HW Bush?

1336.60.text: I am going to guess James.

1340.04.text: I think I would have guessed Jeffrey cos there's an E in it,

1342.84.text:
- but neither is right. It's John. 
- Oh, OK. 
- John Bush. OK, Barry.

1348.20.text: Dean Barrow was re-elected prime minister

1350.88.text: of which Central American state in 2012?

1357.88.text: I don't know the name but that sounds an English name

1363.48.text: so because there's a link to Britain there, I would go for Belize.

1367.28.text: The logic is good and the answer is correct, Barry. Belize it is.

1370.60.text: You've got three out of three. Sorry, Jonny.

1373.00.text:
- Your wrong answer means you have been knocked out. 
- That's OK.

1376.08.text: The Eggheads are pulling back a bit here.

1379.88.text: Come back to us, gents, and we'll see what happens.

1384.12.text: This is what we have been playing towards.

1386.24.text: It's time for the final round which, as always, is General Knowledge.

1389.72.text: I'm afraid those of you who lost your head-to-heads

1392.08.text: won't be allowed to take part in this round,

1394.16.text: so that is Emma and Jonny from Run Camden

1396.44.text: and Pat and Lisa from the Eggheads.

1398.52.text: Would you please leave the studio?

1401.92.text: Well, here we are. Sam, John and Charlotte,

1404.44.text: you were taking them apart, they fought back.

1407.32.text: It is very much a marathon not a sprint, as you can tell,

1410.52.text: so now we're very evenly poised for an exciting final

1414.08.text: and you're playing to win, Run Camden, £19,000.

1417.60.text: Eggheads, you're playing for something that money can't buy,

1421.96.text: and B, the chance to continue this amazing run you're on.

1424.96.text: As usual, I will ask each team three questions in turn.

1427.48.text: The questions are all General Knowledge.

1429.56.text: You are allowed to confer. Run Camden, the question is,

1432.88.text: are your three brains better than the Eggheads' three?

1435.68.text:
- Would you like to go first or second? 
- Second.

1441.96.text: Here we go. Eggheads, your first question.

1444.48.text: On Twitter, what is the maximum number of characters

1447.04.text: that can appear in a public message, known as a tweet?

1456.00.text:
- That's 140. 
- 140 is the right answer. 
- Yeah.

1460.44.text: Challengers, what is the first name

1462.24.text: of the Queen's eldest granddaughter, born in 1981?

1470.48.text:
- I'm pretty sure it's not Beatrice. 
- Yeah.

1473.20.text:
- The other two are much too young. 
- Yeah, it's definitely Zara.

1475.92.text:
- Zara Phillips, isn't it? 
- She's the oldest, yeah. 
- Zara Phillips.

1479.64.text: Zara is the right answer, well done. One each.

1483.28.text: Eggheads, prior to its abolition in the UK,

1485.68.text: what colour cap was worn by judges who passed the death sentence?

1492.80.text:
- Black. 
- Black. 
- Definitely. 
- That was definitely the black cap.

1496.40.text: It was, indeed, the black cap. Well done.

1502.92.text: In Greek mythology, who killed the Trojan warrior Hector?

1513.64.text: I saw a film of this the other day and it was Achilles.

1517.04.text:
- It's Achilles, the warrior Achilles. 
- Achilles. 
- Yeah.

1522.20.text: Achilles is right. Oh, this is a good competition today!

1528.64.text: Eggheads, third question. Get this wrong

1530.60.text: and all they have to do is get the next one right.

1532.84.text: The site of the 1746 Battle of Culloden

1536.24.text: is located near which Scottish city?

1542.64.text: It was at Drumlochy Moor, just outside Inverness.

1544.92.text:
- Yeah. 
- Inverness, yeah. 
- That's definitely Inverness.

1548.80.text: It is definitely Inverness. Well done. You've got three out of three.

1553.32.text: Giving them chance to go first means

1554.88.text: they put you under pressure, so you have to get this one right

1557.88.text: or the contest is over. Take your time. Here it is.

1561.16.text: Every year, the Duke of Marlborough and the Duke of Wellington

1565.04.text: each present the Crown with which item

1567.96.text: as a symbolic rent for their country estate?

1578.36.text:
- Any confident ideas? 
- Both famous soldiers.

1581.52.text: I would confidently discount the French flag.

1584.72.text:
- Who would want a French flag? 
- Barrel of sherry sticks out to me.

1588.56.text:
- I don't know. 
- See, I don't know. I was edging towards cannon ball.

1592.92.text: I'd say, on the basis of them both being...

1595.36.text: their ancestors being the most famous soldiers.

1599.72.text:
- Cannon ball jumps out. 
- Well, none of us know.

1602.24.text:
- Why does barrel of sherry jump out to you? 
- Cos he likes sherry.

1605.00.text: I just think it's barrel of sherry but there's two of you

1607.56.text: and there's one of me. Two of you, one of me.

1610.52.text: A 19-grand punt on a cannon ball.

1615.48.text: Yeah, we've not got a huge amount to go on

1618.40.text: and it's probably going to be French flag now, but cannon ball.

1621.68.text: OK, cannon ball, you say, and if you get this wrong, the contest is over.

1627.08.text: I guess there aren't that many cannon balls around.

1629.80.text: I have got a memory of a barrel of sherry in this, somehow.

1632.68.text: Do you know the answer, Eggheads?

1634.40.text: No, but they both had famous victories against the French,

1637.64.text:
- so I'd be tempted for French flag. 
- It would be too tactless.

1641.76.text: I think it would be too insensitive, a French flag.

1644.56.text: As you can see, this is not easy

1646.32.text: but you've given a reason for French flag.

1648.60.text:
- The answer is French flag. 
- No!

1650.72.text:
- Seriously. 
- Yes, I thought so. 
- I'm amazed.

1652.96.text: Barry would have got that but Judith might have stopped him.

1655.84.text:
- I'd have stopped him. 
- You wouldn't have.

1659.16.text:
- Ah, if only we'd gone the other way round. 
- We'd have argued.

1661.72.text: I'm sorry, Challengers. After a great contest,

1663.84.text: we have to say congratulations, Eggheads, you have won.

1672.00.text: Yeah, they did both have famous victories against the French,

1674.96.text: so it was that one sliver of information

1677.84.text: that might have led you there, but very hard.

1682.32.text: Great contest. Really brilliant watching it from here, thank you.

1685.72.text: The Eggheads have done what comes naturally to them.

1689.84.text: You don't have to put up with any of my training shoe jokes now,

1694.24.text: You won't be going home with the £19,000, back to Camden,

1697.04.text: so that means the money rolls over to our next show.

1699.40.text: Eggheads, congratulations. You are now officially unbeatable.

1702.20.text:
- You can never, never be beaten. 
- Don't say that, please!

1705.40.text: I'm tempting it! Join us next time

1707.60.text: to see if a new team of Challengers have the brains to take them apart.

1711.36.text: My goodness, Run Camden nearly did today.

1713.72.text: It's going to be £20,000 they're playing for next time.
